        </tr>
        <tr>

        <tr>

        </tr>

        <tr>

          <td id="LC31" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L32" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="32"></td>
          <td id="LC32" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Introduction to Optimal Individualized Interventions</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L33" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="33"></td>
          <td id="LC33" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L34" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="34"></td>
          <td id="LC34" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Identifying which intervention will be effective for which patient based on</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L35" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="35"></td>
          <td id="LC35" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">lifestyle, genetic and environmental factors is a common goal in precision</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L36" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="36"></td>
          <td id="LC36" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">medicine. To put it in context, Abacavir and Tenofovir are commonly prescribed</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L37" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="37"></td>
          <td id="LC37" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">as part of the antiretroviral therapy to Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L38" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="38"></td>
          <td id="LC38" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">patients. However, not all individuals benefit from the two medications equally.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L39" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="39"></td>
          <td id="LC39" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In particular, patients with renal dysfunction might further deteriorate if</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L40" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="40"></td>
          <td id="LC40" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">prescribed Tenofovir, due to the high nephrotoxicity caused by the medication.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L41" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="41"></td>
          <td id="LC41" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">While Tenofovir is still highly effective treatment option for HIV patients, in</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L42" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="42"></td>
          <td id="LC42" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">order to maximize the patient&#39;s well-being, it would be beneficial to prescribe</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L43" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="43"></td>
          <td id="LC43" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Tenofovir only to individuals with healthy kidney function. As an another example, </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L44" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="44"></td>
          <td id="LC44" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">consider a HIV trial where our goal is to improve retention in HIV care.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L45" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="45"></td>
          <td id="LC45" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In a randomized clinical trial, several interventions show efficacy- including </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L46" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="46"></td>
          <td id="LC46" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">appointment reminders through text messages, small cash incentives for on time </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L47" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="47"></td>
          <td id="LC47" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">clinic visits, and peer health workers. Ideally, we want to improve effectiveness </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L48" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="48"></td>
          <td id="LC48" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">by assigning each patient the intervention they are most likely to benefit from, </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L49" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="49"></td>
          <td id="LC49" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">as well as improve efficiency by not allocating resources to individuals that do not need</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L50" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="50"></td>
          <td id="LC50" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">them, or would not benefit from it.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L51" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="51"></td>
          <td id="LC51" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L52" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="52"></td>
          <td id="LC52" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r, fig.cap=&quot;Dynamic Treatment Regime in a Clinical Setting&quot;, results=&quot;asis&quot;, echo=FALSE}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L53" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="53"></td>
          <td id="LC53" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-e">knitr</span><span class="pl-k">::</span>include_graphics(<span class="pl-v">path</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span>img/png/DynamicA_Illustration.png<span class="pl-pds">&quot;</span></span>)</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L54" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="54"></td>
          <td id="LC54" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L55" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="55"></td>
          <td id="LC55" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L56" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="56"></td>
          <td id="LC56" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">One opts to administer the intervention to individuals who will profit from it,</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L57" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="57"></td>
          <td id="LC57" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">instead of assigning treatment on a population level. But how do we know which</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L58" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="58"></td>
          <td id="LC58" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">intervention works for which patient? This aim motivates a different type of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L59" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="59"></td>
          <td id="LC59" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">intervention, as opposed to the static exposures we described in previous chapters. </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L60" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="60"></td>
          <td id="LC60" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In particular, in this chapter we learn about dynamic or &quot;individualized&quot;</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L61" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="61"></td>
          <td id="LC61" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">interventions that tailor the treatment decision based on the collected</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L62" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="62"></td>
          <td id="LC62" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">covariates. Formally, dynamic treatments represent interventions that at each</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L63" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="63"></td>
          <td id="LC63" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment-decision stage are allowed to respond to the currently available</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L64" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="64"></td>
          <td id="LC64" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment and covariate history. A dynamic treatment rule can be thought of as</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L65" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="65"></td>
          <td id="LC65" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a rule where the input is the available set of collected covariates, and the </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L66" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="66"></td>
          <td id="LC66" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">output is an individualized treatment for each patient </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L67" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="67"></td>
          <td id="LC67" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">bembom2007realistic</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">robins1986</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">moodie2013</span>].</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L68" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="68"></td>
          <td id="LC68" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L69" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="69"></td>
          <td id="LC69" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In the statistics community such a treatment strategy is termed an</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L70" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="70"></td>
          <td id="LC70" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mb">__individualized treatment regime__</span> (ITR), also known as the optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L71" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="71"></td>
          <td id="LC71" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">dynamic treatment rule, optimal treatment regime, optimal strategy, </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L72" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="72"></td>
          <td id="LC72" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and optimal policy [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">murphy2003</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">robins2004</span>]. The (counterfactual) </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L73" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="73"></td>
          <td id="LC73" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">population mean outcome under an ITR is the value of the ITR [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">murphy2003</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">robins2004</span>].</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L74" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="74"></td>
          <td id="LC74" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Even more, suppose one wishes to maximize the population mean of an</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L75" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="75"></td>
          <td id="LC75" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">outcome, where for each individual we have access to some set of measured</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L76" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="76"></td>
          <td id="LC76" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">covariates. This means, for example, that we can learn for which individual</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L77" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="77"></td>
          <td id="LC77" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">characteristics assigning treatment increases the probability of a beneficial</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L78" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="78"></td>
          <td id="LC78" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">outcome. An ITR with the maximal value is referred to as an</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L79" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="79"></td>
          <td id="LC79" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">optimal ITR or the <span class="pl-mb">__optimal individualized treatment__</span>. Consequently, the value</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L80" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="80"></td>
          <td id="LC80" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of an optimal ITR is termed the optimal value, or the </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L81" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="81"></td>
          <td id="LC81" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mb">__mean under the optimal individualized treatment__</span>.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L82" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="82"></td>
          <td id="LC82" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L83" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="83"></td>
          <td id="LC83" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The problem of estimating the optimal individualized treatment has received much</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L84" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="84"></td>
          <td id="LC84" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">attention in the statistics literature over the years, especially with the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L85" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="85"></td>
          <td id="LC85" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">advancement of precision medicine; see <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">murphy2003</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">robins2004</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">laber2012</span>,</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L86" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="86"></td>
          <td id="LC86" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">kosorok2012</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">moodie2013</span> and <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">robins2014</span> to name a few. However, much of the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L87" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="87"></td>
          <td id="LC87" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">early work depends on parametric assumptions. As such, even in a randomized</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L88" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="88"></td>
          <td id="LC88" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">trial, the statistical inference for the optimal individualized treatment relies</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L89" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="89"></td>
          <td id="LC89" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">on assumptions that are generally believed to be false, and can lead to biased</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L90" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="90"></td>
          <td id="LC90" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">results.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L91" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="91"></td>
          <td id="LC91" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L92" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="92"></td>
          <td id="LC92" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In this chapter, we consider estimation of the mean outcome under the optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L93" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="93"></td>
          <td id="LC93" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">individualized treatment where the candidate rules are restricted to depend only</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L94" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="94"></td>
          <td id="LC94" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">on user-supplied subset of the baseline covariates. The estimation problem is</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L95" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="95"></td>
          <td id="LC95" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">addressed in a statistical model for the data distribution that is</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L96" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="96"></td>
          <td id="LC96" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">nonparametric, and at most places restrictions on the probability of a patient</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L97" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="97"></td>
          <td id="LC97" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">receiving treatment given covariates (as in a randomized trial). As such, we</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L98" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="98"></td>
          <td id="LC98" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">don&#39;t need to make any assumptions about the relationship of the outcome with</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L99" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="99"></td>
          <td id="LC99" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the treatment and covariates, or the relationship between the treatment and</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L100" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="100"></td>
          <td id="LC100" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">covariates. Further, we provide a Targeted Maximum Likelihood Estimator for the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L101" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="101"></td>
          <td id="LC101" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mean under the optimal individualized treatment that allows us to generate valid</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L102" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="102"></td>
          <td id="LC102" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">inference for our parameter, without having any parametric assumptions. </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L103" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="103"></td>
          <td id="LC103" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L104" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="104"></td>
          <td id="LC104" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In the following, we provide a brief overview of the methodology with a focus on</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L105" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="105"></td>
          <td id="LC105" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">building intuition for the target parameter and its importance --- aided with simulations, </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L106" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="106"></td>
          <td id="LC106" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">data examples and software demonstrations. For more information on the technical aspects</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L107" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="107"></td>
          <td id="LC107" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the algorithm, further practical advice and overview, the interested reader is invited to </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L108" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="108"></td>
          <td id="LC108" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">additionally consult <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">vanderLaanLuedtke15</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">luedtke2016super</span>, <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">montoya2021optimal</span> and </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L109" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="109"></td>
          <td id="LC109" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">montoya2021performance</span>. </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L110" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="110"></td>
          <td id="LC110" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L111" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="111"></td>
          <td id="LC111" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c">---</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L112" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="112"></td>
          <td id="LC112" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L113" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="113"></td>
          <td id="LC113" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Data Structure and Notation</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L114" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="114"></td>
          <td id="LC114" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L115" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="115"></td>
          <td id="LC115" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Suppose we observe $n$ independent and identically distributed observations of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L116" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="116"></td>
          <td id="LC116" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the form $O=(W,A,Y) <span class="pl-cce">\s</span>im P_0$. We denote $A$ as categorical treatment, and $Y$</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L117" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="117"></td>
          <td id="LC117" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">as the final outcome. In particular, we define $A <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{A}$ where</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L118" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="118"></td>
          <td id="LC118" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{A} <span class="pl-cce">\e</span>quiv <span class="pl-cce">\{</span>a_1, <span class="pl-cce">\c</span>dots, a_{n_A} <span class="pl-cce">\}</span>$ and $n_A = |<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{A}|$, with</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L119" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="119"></td>
          <td id="LC119" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$n_A$ denoting the number of categories (possibly only two, for a binary setup).</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L120" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="120"></td>
          <td id="LC120" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Note that we treat $W$ as vector-valued, representing all of our collected</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L121" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="121"></td>
          <td id="LC121" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">baseline covariates. Therefore, for a single random individual $i$, we have that</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L122" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="122"></td>
          <td id="LC122" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">their observed data is $O_i$: with corresponding baseline covariates $W_i$,</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L123" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="123"></td>
          <td id="LC123" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment $A_i$, and final outcome $Y_i$. Let $O^n = <span class="pl-cce">\{</span>O_i<span class="pl-cce">\}</span>_{i=1}^n$ denote</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L124" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="124"></td>
          <td id="LC124" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$n$ observed samples. Then, we say that $O^n <span class="pl-cce">\s</span>im P_0$, or that all</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L125" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="125"></td>
          <td id="LC125" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">data was drawn from some true probability distribution $P_0$. Let $<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{M}$</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L126" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="126"></td>
          <td id="LC126" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">denote a statistical model for the probability distribution of the data that is</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L127" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="127"></td>
          <td id="LC127" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">nonparametric, beyond possible knowledge of the treatment mechanism. In words, this </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L128" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="128"></td>
          <td id="LC128" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">means that we make no assumptions on the relationship between variables, but might </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L129" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="129"></td>
          <td id="LC129" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">be able to say something about the relationship of $A$ and $W$, as is the case in </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L130" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="130"></td>
          <td id="LC130" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a randomized trial. In general, the more we know, or are willing to assume about the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L131" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="131"></td>
          <td id="LC131" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">experiment that produces the data, the smaller the model. The true data generating </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L132" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="132"></td>
          <td id="LC132" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distribution $P_0$ is part of the statistical model $<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{M}$, and we write </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L133" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="133"></td>
          <td id="LC133" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$P_0 <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{M}$. As in previous chapters, we denote $P_n$ as the empirical distribution</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L134" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="134"></td>
          <td id="LC134" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">which gives each observation weight $1/n$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L135" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="135"></td>
          <td id="LC135" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L136" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="136"></td>
          <td id="LC136" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We use the structural equation model (SEM) in order to define</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L137" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="137"></td>
          <td id="LC137" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the process that gives rise to the observed (endogenous) and not observed</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L138" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="138"></td>
          <td id="LC138" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(exogenous) variables, as described by <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">pearl2009causality</span>. In particular, we</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L139" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="139"></td>
          <td id="LC139" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">denote $U=(U_W,U_A,U_Y)$ as the exogenous random variables, drawn from $U <span class="pl-cce">\s</span>im P_U$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L140" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="140"></td>
          <td id="LC140" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The endogenous variables, written as $O=(W,A,Y)$, correspond to the observed data.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L141" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="141"></td>
          <td id="LC141" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We can define the relationships between variables with the following structural equations:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L142" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="142"></td>
          <td id="LC142" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\b</span>egin{align}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L143" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="143"></td>
          <td id="LC143" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  W &amp;= f_W(U_W) <span class="pl-cce">\\</span> A &amp;= f_A(W, U_A) <span class="pl-cce">\\</span> Y &amp;= f_Y(A, W, U_Y),</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L144" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="144"></td>
          <td id="LC144" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  (<span class="pl-cce">\#</span>eq:npsem-mopttx)</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L145" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="145"></td>
          <td id="LC145" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\e</span>nd{align}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L146" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="146"></td>
          <td id="LC146" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">where the collection $f=(f_W,f_A,f_Y)$ denotes unspecified functions, beyond possible </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L147" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="147"></td>
          <td id="LC147" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">knowledge of the treatment mechanism function, $f_A$. Note that</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L148" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="148"></td>
          <td id="LC148" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the case of a randomized trial, we can write the above NPSEM as</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L149" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="149"></td>
          <td id="LC149" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\b</span>egin{align}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L150" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="150"></td>
          <td id="LC150" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  W &amp;= f_W(U_W) <span class="pl-cce">\\</span> A &amp;= U_A <span class="pl-cce">\\</span> Y &amp;= f_Y(A, W, U_Y),</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L151" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="151"></td>
          <td id="LC151" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  (<span class="pl-cce">\#</span>eq:npsem-rt-mopttx)</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L152" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="152"></td>
          <td id="LC152" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\e</span>nd{align}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L153" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="153"></td>
          <td id="LC153" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">where $U_A$ has a known distribution and $U_A$ is independent of $U_W$. We will discuss</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L154" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="154"></td>
          <td id="LC154" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">this more in later sections on identifiability.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L155" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="155"></td>
          <td id="LC155" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L156" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="156"></td>
          <td id="LC156" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The likelihood of the data admits a factorization, implied by the time ordering</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L157" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="157"></td>
          <td id="LC157" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of $O$. We denote the true density of $O$ as $p_0$, corresponding to the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L158" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="158"></td>
          <td id="LC158" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distribution $P_0$ and dominating measure $<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>u$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L159" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="159"></td>
          <td id="LC159" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\b</span>egin{equation}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L160" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="160"></td>
          <td id="LC160" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  p_0(O) = p_{Y,0}(Y <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id A,W) p_{A,0}(A <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W) p_{W,0}(W) =</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L161" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="161"></td>
          <td id="LC161" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">    q_{Y,0}(Y <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id A,W) g_{A,0}(A <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W) q_{W,0}(W),</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L162" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="162"></td>
          <td id="LC162" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  (<span class="pl-cce">\#</span>eq:likelihood-factorization-mopttx)</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L163" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="163"></td>
          <td id="LC163" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\e</span>nd{equation}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L164" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="164"></td>
          <td id="LC164" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">where $p_{Y,0}(Y|A,W)$ is the conditional density of $Y$ given $(A, W)$ with</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L165" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="165"></td>
          <td id="LC165" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">respect to some dominating measure $<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>u_Y$, $p_{A,0}$ is the conditional density</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L166" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="166"></td>
          <td id="LC166" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of $A$ given $W$ with respect to a counting measure $<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>u_A$, and $p_{W,0}$ is</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L167" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="167"></td>
          <td id="LC167" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the density of $W$ with respect to dominating measure $<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>u_W$. In order to </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L168" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="168"></td>
          <td id="LC168" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">match relevant Targeted Learning literature, we also </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L169" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="169"></td>
          <td id="LC169" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">write $P_{Y,0}(Y <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id A, W) = Q_{Y,0}(Y <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id A,W)$, $P_{A,0}(A <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W) = g_0(A <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W)$ </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L170" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="170"></td>
          <td id="LC170" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and $P_{W,0}(W)=Q_{W,0}(W)$ as the corresponding conditional</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L171" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="171"></td>
          <td id="LC171" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distribution of $Y$ given $(A,W)$, treatment mechanism $A$ given $W$, and</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L172" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="172"></td>
          <td id="LC172" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distribution of baseline covariates. For notational simplicity, we additionally define</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L173" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="173"></td>
          <td id="LC173" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{Y,0}(A,W) <span class="pl-cce">\e</span>quiv <span class="pl-cce">\E</span>_0[Y <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id A,W]$ as the conditional expectation of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L174" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="174"></td>
          <td id="LC174" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$Y$ given $(A,W)$.</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L175" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="175"></td>
          <td id="LC175" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L176" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="176"></td>
          <td id="LC176" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Lastly, we define $V$ as a subset of the baseline covariates the optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L177" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="177"></td>
          <td id="LC177" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">individualized rule depends on, where $V <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n W$.  Note that $V$ could be all of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L178" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="178"></td>
          <td id="LC178" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$W$, or an empty set, depending on the subject matter knowledge. In particular,</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L179" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="179"></td>
          <td id="LC179" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a researcher might want to consider known effect modifiers available at the time</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L180" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="180"></td>
          <td id="LC180" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of treatment decision as possible $V$ covariates, or consider dynamic treatment </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L181" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="181"></td>
          <td id="LC181" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rules based on measurments that can be easily obtained in a clinical setting.</td>

          <td id="LC182" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Defining $V$ as a more restrictive set of baseline covariates allows us to consider </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L183" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="183"></td>
          <td id="LC183" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">possibly sub-optimal rules that are easier to estimate, and thereby allows for </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>

          <td id="LC184" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">statistical inference for the counterfactual mean outcome under the sub-optimal rule; </td>

</td>

          <td id="LC190" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{D}$. Then, in a point treatment setting, $d$ is a deterministic function </td>

          <td id="LC192" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$V <span class="pl-cce">\r</span>ightarrow d(V) <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n <span class="pl-cce">\{</span>a_1, <span class="pl-cce">\c</span>dots, a_{n_A} <span class="pl-cce">\}</span>$. We will use dynamic treatment rules, </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L193" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="193"></td>
          <td id="LC193" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and the corresponding treatment decision, to describe an intervention on the </td>

          <td id="LC194" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment mechanism and the corresponding outcome under a dynamic treatment rule.</td>

</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L196" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="196"></td>
          <td id="LC196" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">As mentioned in the previous section, causal effects are defined in terms of</td>

          <td id="LC197" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">hypothetical interventions on the SEM <span class="pl-cce">\@</span>ref(eq:npsem-mopttx). For a given </td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L198" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="198"></td>
          <td id="LC198" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rule $d$, our modified system then takes the following form:</td>

          <td id="LC200" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  W &amp;= f_W(U_W) <span class="pl-cce">\\</span> A &amp;= d(V) <span class="pl-cce">\\</span> Y_{d(V)} &amp;= f_Y(d(V), W, U_Y),</td>

          <td id="LC203" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">where the dynamic treatment regime may be viewed as an intervention in which $A$</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L204" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="204"></td>
          <td id="LC204" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">is set equal to a value based on a hypothetical regime $d(V)$. The couterfactual outcome </td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L205" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="205"></td>
          <td id="LC205" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$Y_{d(V)}$ denotes the outcome for a patient had their treatment been assigned using the </td>

</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L213" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="213"></td>
          <td id="LC213" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The goal of any causal analysis motivated by such dynamic interventions is to</td>

          <td id="LC218" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&quot;What is the expected outcome had every subject received treatment according to the </td>

</td>

          <td id="LC224" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">where the optimal individualized rule is the rule with the maximal value. We note that, in case </td>

</td>

</td>

</td>

          <td id="LC268" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Finally, the statistical counterpart to the causal parameter of interest is</td>

</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L282" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="282"></td>
          <td id="LC282" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Many methods for learning the optimal rule from data have been developed</td>

          <td id="LC283" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">murphy2003</span>; <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">robins2004</span>; <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">laber2012</span>; <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">kosorok2012</span>; <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">moodie2013</span>]. In this</td>

</td>

</td>

</td>

          <td id="LC301" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">How do we estimate the optimal individualized treatment regime? In the case of a</td>

          <td id="LC306" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">negative. Therefore for a binary treatment, under causal assumptions, we define</td>

</td>

          <td id="L314" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="314"></td>
          <td id="LC314" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The package <span class="pl-c1">`tmle3mopttx`</span> relies on using the Super Learner to estimate the blip</td>

          <td id="L315" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="315"></td>

          <td id="L317" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="317"></td>
          <td id="LC317" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mentioning that <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">luedtke2016super</span> present three different approaches for learning the optimal</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L318" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="318"></td>

</td>
