        <tr>
          <td id="L325" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="325"></td>
          <td id="LC325" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">implied by estimators of the blip as well as estimators that directly go for</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L326" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="326"></td>
          <td id="LC326" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$d_0$ through weighted classification.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L327" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="327"></td>
          <td id="LC327" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L328" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="328"></td>
          <td id="LC328" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">A benefit of relying on the blip function, as implemented in <span class="pl-c1">`tmle3mopttx`</span>, is that</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L329" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="329"></td>
          <td id="LC329" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">one can look at the distribution of the predicted outcomes of the blip for a given </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L330" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="330"></td>
          <td id="LC330" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sample. Having an estimate of the blip allows one to identify patients in the sample </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L331" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="331"></td>
          <td id="LC331" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">who benefit the most (or the least) from treatment. Additionally, blip-based approach</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L332" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="332"></td>
          <td id="LC332" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">allows for straight-forward extension to the categorical treatment, interpretable rules, </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L333" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="333"></td>
          <td id="LC333" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and OIT under resource constrains, where only a percent of the population can receive </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L334" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="334"></td>
          <td id="LC334" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment [<span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">luedtke2016resource</span>].</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L335" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="335"></td>
          <td id="LC335" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L336" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="336"></td>
          <td id="LC336" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Relying on the Targeted Maximum Likelihood (TML) estimator and the Super Learner</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L337" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="337"></td>
          <td id="LC337" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">estimate of the blip function, we follow the below steps in order to obtain</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L338" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="338"></td>
          <td id="LC338" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">value of the ITR:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L339" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="339"></td>
          <td id="LC339" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L340" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="340"></td>
          <td id="LC340" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">1.</span> Estimate $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{Y,0}(A,W)$ and $g_0(A <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W)$ using <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span>. We denote such</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L341" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="341"></td>
          <td id="LC341" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   estimates as $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{Y,n}(A,W)$ and $g_n(A <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W)$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L342" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="342"></td>
          <td id="LC342" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">2.</span> Apply the doubly robust Augmented-Inverse Probability Weighted (A-IPW)</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L343" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="343"></td>
          <td id="LC343" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   transform to our outcome (double-robust pseudo-outcome), where we define:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L344" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="344"></td>
          <td id="LC344" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   $$D_{<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_Y,g,a}(O) <span class="pl-cce">\e</span>quiv <span class="pl-cce">\f</span>rac{<span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athbb{I}(A=a)}{g(A <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W)} (Y -</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L345" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="345"></td>
          <td id="LC345" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   <span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_Y(A,W)) + <span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_Y(A=a,W).$$</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L346" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="346"></td>
          <td id="LC346" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L347" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="347"></td>
          <td id="LC347" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Note that under the randomization and positivity assumptions we have that</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L348" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="348"></td>
          <td id="LC348" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$<span class="pl-cce">\E</span>[D_{<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_Y,g,a}(O) <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id V] = <span class="pl-cce">\E</span>[Y_a <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id V]$. We emphasize the double</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L349" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="349"></td>
          <td id="LC349" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">robust nature of the A-IPW transform --- consistency of $<span class="pl-cce">\E</span>[Y_a <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id V]$ will depend</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L350" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="350"></td>
          <td id="LC350" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">on correct estimation of either $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{Y,0}(A,W)$ or $g_0(A <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W)$. As</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L351" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="351"></td>
          <td id="LC351" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">such, in a randomized trial, we are guaranteed a consistent estimate of $<span class="pl-cce">\E</span>[Y_a <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id V]$ </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L352" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="352"></td>
          <td id="LC352" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">even if we get $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{Y,0}(A,W)$ wrong! An alternative to the double-robust pseudo-outcome</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L353" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="353"></td>
          <td id="LC353" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">just presented would be single stage Q-learning, where an estimate $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{Y,0}(A,W)$ </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L354" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="354"></td>
          <td id="LC354" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">is used to predict at $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}<span class="pl-mi">_{Y,n}(A=1,W)$ and $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_</span>{Y,n}(A=0,W)$. This provides</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L355" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="355"></td>
          <td id="LC355" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">an estimate of the blip function, $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}<span class="pl-mi">_{Y,n}(A=1,W) - <span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_</span>{Y,n}(A=0,W)$, but</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L356" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="356"></td>
          <td id="LC356" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">relies on doing a good job on estimating $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{Y,0}(A,W)$. </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L357" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="357"></td>
          <td id="LC357" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L358" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="358"></td>
          <td id="LC358" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Using the double-robust pseudo-outcome, we can define the following contrast:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L359" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="359"></td>
          <td id="LC359" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$$D_{<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}<span class="pl-mi">_Y,g}(O) = D_</span>{<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}<span class="pl-mi">_Y, g, a=1}(O) - D_</span>{<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_Y, g, a=0}(O).$$</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L360" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="360"></td>
          <td id="LC360" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L361" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="361"></td>
          <td id="LC361" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L362" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="362"></td>
          <td id="LC362" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We estimate the blip function, $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{0,a}(V)$, by regressing</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L363" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="363"></td>
          <td id="LC363" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$D_{<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_Y,g}(O)$ on $V$ using the specified <span class="pl-c1">`sl3`</span> library of learners and an</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L364" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="364"></td>
          <td id="LC364" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">appropriate loss function. Finally, we are ready for the final steps. </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L365" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="365"></td>
          <td id="LC365" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L366" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="366"></td>
          <td id="LC366" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">3.</span> Our estimated rule corresponds to $<span class="pl-cce">\t</span>ext{argmax}_{a <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{A}}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L367" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="367"></td>
          <td id="LC367" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   <span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{0,a}(V)$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L368" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="368"></td>
          <td id="LC368" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L369" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="369"></td>
          <td id="LC369" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">4.</span> We obtain inference for the mean outcome under the estimated optimal rule</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L370" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="370"></td>
          <td id="LC370" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   using CV-TMLE.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L371" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="371"></td>
          <td id="LC371" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L372" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="372"></td>
          <td id="LC372" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Categorical treatment</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L373" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="373"></td>
          <td id="LC373" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L374" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="374"></td>
          <td id="LC374" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In line with the approach considered for binary treatment, we extend the blip</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L375" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="375"></td>
          <td id="LC375" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">function to allow for categorical treatment. We denote such blip function</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L376" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="376"></td>
          <td id="LC376" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">extensions as <span class="pl-mi">_pseudo-blips_</span>, which are our new estimation targets in a</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L377" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="377"></td>
          <td id="LC377" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">categorical setting. We define pseudo-blips as vector-valued entities where the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L378" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="378"></td>
          <td id="LC378" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">output for a given $V$ is a vector of length equal to the number of treatment</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L379" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="379"></td>
          <td id="LC379" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">categories, $n_A$. As such, we define it as:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L380" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="380"></td>
          <td id="LC380" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">$$<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}<span class="pl-mi">_0^{pblip}(V) = <span class="pl-cce">\{\b</span>ar{Q}_</span>{0,a}^{pblip}(V): a <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{A} <span class="pl-cce">\}</span>$$</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L381" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="381"></td>
          <td id="LC381" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L382" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="382"></td>
          <td id="LC382" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">We implement three different pseudo-blips in <span class="pl-c1">`tmle3mopttx`</span>.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L383" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="383"></td>
          <td id="LC383" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L384" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="384"></td>
          <td id="LC384" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">1.</span> <span class="pl-mi">_Blip1_</span> corresponds to choosing a reference category of treatment, and</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L385" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="385"></td>
          <td id="LC385" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   defining the blip for all other categories relative to the specified</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L386" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="386"></td>
          <td id="LC386" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   reference. Hence we have that:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L387" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="387"></td>
          <td id="LC387" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   $$<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{0,a}^{pblip-ref}(V) <span class="pl-cce">\e</span>quiv <span class="pl-cce">\E</span>_0[Y_a-Y_0 <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id V]$$ where $Y_0$ is</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L388" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="388"></td>
          <td id="LC388" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   the specified reference category with $A=0$. Note that, for the case of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L389" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="389"></td>
          <td id="LC389" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   binary treatment, this strategy reduces to the approach described for the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L390" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="390"></td>
          <td id="LC390" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   binary setup.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L391" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="391"></td>
          <td id="LC391" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L392" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="392"></td>
          <td id="LC392" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">2.</span> <span class="pl-mi">_Blip2_</span> approach corresponds to defining the blip relative to the average of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L393" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="393"></td>
          <td id="LC393" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   all categories. As such, we can define $<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}_{0,a}^{pblip-avg}(V)$ as:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L394" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="394"></td>
          <td id="LC394" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   $$<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}<span class="pl-mi">_{0,a}^{pblip-avg}(V) <span class="pl-cce">\e</span>quiv <span class="pl-cce">\E</span>_0 [Y_a - <span class="pl-cce">\f</span>rac{1}{n_A} <span class="pl-cce">\s</span>um_</span>{a <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L395" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="395"></td>
          <td id="LC395" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{A}} Y_a <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id V].$$</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L396" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="396"></td>
          <td id="LC396" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   In the case where subject-matter knowledge regarding which reference category</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L397" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="397"></td>
          <td id="LC397" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   to use is not available, blip2 might be a viable option.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L398" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="398"></td>
          <td id="LC398" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L399" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="399"></td>
          <td id="LC399" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-v">3.</span> <span class="pl-mi">_Blip3_</span> reflects an extension of Blip2, where the average is now a weighted</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L400" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="400"></td>
          <td id="LC400" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   average:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L401" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="401"></td>
          <td id="LC401" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">   $$<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>ar{Q}<span class="pl-mi">_{0,a}^{pblip-wavg}(V) <span class="pl-cce">\e</span>quiv <span class="pl-cce">\E</span>_0 [ Y_a - <span class="pl-cce">\f</span>rac{1}{n_A} <span class="pl-cce">\s</span>um_</span>{a <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L402" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="402"></td>
          <td id="LC402" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{A}} Y_{a} P(A=a <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id V) <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id V ].$$</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L403" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="403"></td>
          <td id="LC403" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L404" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="404"></td>
          <td id="LC404" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Just like in the binary case, pseudo-blips are estimated by regressing contrasts</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L405" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="405"></td>
          <td id="LC405" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">composed using the A-IPW transform on $V$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L406" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="406"></td>
          <td id="LC406" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L407" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="407"></td>
          <td id="LC407" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Technical Note: Inference and data-adaptive parameter</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L408" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="408"></td>
          <td id="LC408" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L409" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="409"></td>
          <td id="LC409" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In a randomized trial, statistical inference relies on the second-order</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L410" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="410"></td>
          <td id="LC410" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">difference between the estimate of the optimal individualized treatment and the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L411" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="411"></td>
          <td id="LC411" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">optimal individualized treatment itself to be asymptotically negligible. This is</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L412" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="412"></td>
          <td id="LC412" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a reasonable condition if we consider rules that depend on a small number of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L413" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="413"></td>
          <td id="LC413" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">covariates, or if we are willing to make smoothness assumptions. Alternatively,</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L414" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="414"></td>
          <td id="LC414" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">we can consider TMLEs and statistical inference for data-adaptive target</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L415" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="415"></td>
          <td id="LC415" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">parameters defined in terms of an estimate of the optimal individualized</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L416" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="416"></td>
          <td id="LC416" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment. In particular, instead of trying to estimate the mean under the true</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L417" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="417"></td>
          <td id="LC417" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">optimal individualized treatment, we aim to estimate the mean under the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L418" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="418"></td>
          <td id="LC418" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">estimated optimal individualized treatment. As such, we develop cross-validated</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L419" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="419"></td>
          <td id="LC419" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">TMLE approach that provides asymptotic inference under minimal conditions for</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L420" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="420"></td>
          <td id="LC420" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the mean under the estimate of the optimal individualized treatment. In</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L421" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="421"></td>
          <td id="LC421" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">particular, considering the data adaptive parameter allows us to avoid</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L422" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="422"></td>
          <td id="LC422" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">consistency and rate condition for the fitted optimal rule, as required for</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L423" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="423"></td>
          <td id="LC423" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">asymptotic linearity of the TMLE of the mean under the actual, true optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L424" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="424"></td>
          <td id="LC424" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rule. Practically, the estimated (data-adaptive) rule should be preferred, as</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L425" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="425"></td>
          <td id="LC425" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">this possibly sub-optimal rule is the one implemented in the population.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L426" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="426"></td>
          <td id="LC426" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L427" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="427"></td>
          <td id="LC427" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Technical Note: Why CV-TMLE?</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L428" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="428"></td>
          <td id="LC428" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L429" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="429"></td>
          <td id="LC429" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">As discussed in <span class="pl-v">@</span><span class="pl-s">vanderLaanLuedtke15</span>, CV-TMLE is necessary as the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L430" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="430"></td>
          <td id="LC430" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">non-cross-validated TMLE is biased upward for the mean outcome under the rule,</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L431" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="431"></td>
          <td id="LC431" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and therefore overly optimistic. More generally however, using CV-TMLE allows us</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L432" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="432"></td>
          <td id="LC432" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">more freedom in estimation and therefore greater data adaptivity, without</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L433" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="433"></td>
          <td id="LC433" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sacrificing inference.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L434" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="434"></td>
          <td id="LC434" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L435" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="435"></td>
          <td id="LC435" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Interpreting the Causal Effect of an Optimal Individualized Intervention</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L436" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="436"></td>
          <td id="LC436" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L437" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="437"></td>
          <td id="LC437" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In summary, the mean outcome under the optimal individualized treatment is a</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L438" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="438"></td>
          <td id="LC438" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">counterfactual quantity of interest representing what the mean outcome would</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L439" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="439"></td>
          <td id="LC439" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">have been if everybody, contrary to the fact, received treatment that optimized</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L440" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="440"></td>
          <td id="LC440" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">their outcome. The optimal individualized treatment regime is a rule that</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L441" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="441"></td>
          <td id="LC441" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">optimizes the mean outcome under the dynamic treatment, where the candidate</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L442" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="442"></td>
          <td id="LC442" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rules are restricted to only respond to a user-supplied subset of the baseline</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L443" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="443"></td>
          <td id="LC443" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">covariates. In essence, our target parameter answers the key</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L444" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="444"></td>
          <td id="LC444" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">aim of precision medicine: allocating the available treatment by tailoring it to</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L445" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="445"></td>
          <td id="LC445" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the individual characteristics of the patient, with the goal of optimizing the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L446" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="446"></td>
          <td id="LC446" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">final outcome.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L447" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="447"></td>
          <td id="LC447" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L448" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="448"></td>
          <td id="LC448" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Evaluating the Causal Effect of an OIT with Binary Treatment {#oit-eval-bin}</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L449" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="449"></td>
          <td id="LC449" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L450" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="450"></td>
          <td id="LC450" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Finally, we demonstrate how to evaluate the mean outcome under the optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L451" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="451"></td>
          <td id="LC451" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">individualized treatment using <span class="pl-c1">`tmle3mopptx`</span>. To start, let&#39;s load the packages</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L452" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="452"></td>
          <td id="LC452" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">we&#39;ll use and set a seed:</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L453" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="453"></td>
          <td id="LC453" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>

          <td id="LC454" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r setup-mopttx}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>

        <tr>

          <td id="LC455" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">library(<span class="pl-smi">data.table</span>)</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>

          <td id="LC456" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">library(<span class="pl-smi">sl3</span>)</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L457" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="457"></td>
          <td id="LC457" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">library(<span class="pl-smi">tmle3</span>)</span></td>

        <tr>

        <tr>

        <tr>

        <tr>

          <td id="LC461" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1">set.seed(<span class="pl-c1">111</span>)</span></td>

        <tr>

          <td id="LC463" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L464" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="464"></td>
          <td id="LC464" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Simulated Data</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L465" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="465"></td>
          <td id="LC465" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L466" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="466"></td>
          <td id="LC466" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">First, we load the simulated data. We will start with the more general setup</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L467" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="467"></td>
          <td id="LC467" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">where the treatment is a binary variable; later in the chapter we will consider</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L468" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="468"></td>
          <td id="LC468" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">another data-generating distribution where $A$ is categorical. In this example,</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L469" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="469"></td>
          <td id="LC469" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">our data generating distribution is of the following form:</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L470" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="470"></td>
          <td id="LC470" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-cce">\b</span>egin{align*}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L471" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="471"></td>
          <td id="LC471" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  W &amp;<span class="pl-cce">\s</span>im <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>athcal{N}(<span class="pl-cce">\b</span>f{0},I_{3 <span class="pl-cce">\t</span>imes 3})<span class="pl-cce">\\</span></td>

        <tr>

          <td id="LC472" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  <span class="pl-cce">\P</span>(A=1 <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id W) &amp;= <span class="pl-cce">\f</span>rac{1}{1+<span class="pl-cce">\e</span>xp^{(-0.8*W_1)}}<span class="pl-cce">\\</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L473" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="473"></td>
          <td id="LC473" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">  <span class="pl-cce">\P</span>(Y=1 <span class="pl-cce">\m</span>id A,W) &amp;= 0.5<span class="pl-cce">\t</span>ext{logit}^{-1}[-5I(A=1)(W_1-0.5)+5I(A=0)(W_1-0.5)] +</td>

        <tr>

        <tr>

        <tr>

</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L477" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="477"></td>
          <td id="LC477" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r load sim_bin_data}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
        </tr>

          <td id="L679" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="679"></td>

          <td id="L808" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="808"></td>
          <td id="LC808" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Extensions to Causal Effect of an OIT</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L809" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="809"></td>
          <td id="LC809" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L810" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="810"></td>
          <td id="LC810" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In this section, we consider two extensions to the procedure described for</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L811" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="811"></td>
          <td id="LC811" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">estimating the value of the OIT. First one considers a setting where the user</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L812" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="812"></td>
          <td id="LC812" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">might be interested in a grid of possible sub-optimal rules, corresponding to</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L813" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="813"></td>
          <td id="LC813" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">potentially limited knowledge of potential effect modifiers. The second</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L814" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="814"></td>
          <td id="LC814" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">extension concerns implementation of a realistic optimal individual</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L815" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="815"></td>
          <td id="LC815" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">interventions where certain regimes might be preferred, but due to practical or</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L816" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="816"></td>
          <td id="LC816" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">global positivity restraints, are not realistic to implement.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L817" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="817"></td>
          <td id="LC817" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L818" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="818"></td>
          <td id="LC818" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Simpler Rules {#oit-eval-cat-v2}</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L819" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="819"></td>
          <td id="LC819" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L820" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="820"></td>
          <td id="LC820" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In order to not only consider the most ambitious fully $V$-optimal rule, we</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L821" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="821"></td>
          <td id="LC821" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">define $S$-optimal rules as the optimal rule that considers all possible subsets</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L822" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="822"></td>
          <td id="LC822" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of $V$ covariates, with card($S$) $<span class="pl-cce">\l</span>eq$ card($V$) and $<span class="pl-cce">\e</span>mptyset <span class="pl-cce">\i</span>n S$. In </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L823" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="823"></td>
          <td id="LC823" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">particular, this allows us to define a Super Learner for $d_0$ that includes</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L824" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="824"></td>
          <td id="LC824" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a range of estimators from very simple (e.g., statis rules) to more complex </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L825" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="825"></td>
          <td id="LC825" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(e.g. full $V$), and let the discrete Super Learner select a simple rule when </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L826" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="826"></td>
          <td id="LC826" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">appropriate. This allows us to consider sub-optimal rules that are easier to estimate and</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L827" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="827"></td>
          <td id="LC827" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">potentially provide more realistic rules. Within the <span class="pl-c1">`tmle3mopttx`</span> paradigm, we just need </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L828" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="828"></td>
          <td id="LC828" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to change the <span class="pl-c1">`complex`</span> parameter to <span class="pl-c1">`FALSE`</span>:</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L829" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="829"></td>
          <td id="LC829" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>

          <td id="LC966" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"></span><span class="pl-c1">```</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L967" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="967"></td>
          <td id="LC967" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L968" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="968"></td>
          <td id="LC968" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">##</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Variable Importance Analysis with OIT</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L969" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="969"></td>
          <td id="LC969" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L970" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="970"></td>
          <td id="LC970" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Suppose one wishes to assess the importance of each observed covariate, in</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L971" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="971"></td>
          <td id="LC971" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">terms of maximizing (or minimizing) the population mean of an outcome under an</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L972" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="972"></td>
          <td id="LC972" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">optimal individualized treatment regime. In particular, a covariate that</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L973" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="973"></td>
          <td id="LC973" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">maximizes (or minimizes) the population mean outcome the most under an optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L974" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="974"></td>
          <td id="LC974" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">individualized treatment out of all other considered covariates under optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L975" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="975"></td>
          <td id="LC975" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">assignment might be considered <span class="pl-mi">_more important_</span> for the outcome. To put it in</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L976" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="976"></td>
          <td id="LC976" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">context, perhaps optimal allocation of treatment 1, denoted $A_1$, results in a</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L977" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="977"></td>
          <td id="LC977" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">larger mean outcome than optimal allocation of another treatment 2, denoted $A_2$.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L978" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="978"></td>
          <td id="LC978" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Therefore, we would label $A_1$ as having a higher variable importance with</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L979" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="979"></td>
          <td id="LC979" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">regard to maximizing (or minimizing) the mean outcome under the optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L980" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="980"></td>
          <td id="LC980" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">individualized treatment.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L981" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="981"></td>
          <td id="LC981" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L982" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="982"></td>
          <td id="LC982" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Simulated Data</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L983" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="983"></td>
          <td id="LC983" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L984" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="984"></td>
          <td id="LC984" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">For illustration purpose, we bin baseline covariates corresponding to </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L985" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="985"></td>
          <td id="LC985" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the data-generating distribution [<span class="pl-e">described previously</span>](#oit-eval):</td>

        </tr>

          <td id="LC989" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">data</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">W1</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span>ifelse(<span class="pl-smi">data</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">W1</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>quantile(<span class="pl-smi">data</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">W1</span>)[<span class="pl-c1">2</span>],<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,ifelse(<span class="pl-smi">data</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">W1</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>quantile(<span class="pl-smi">data</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">W1</span>)[<span class="pl-c1">3</span>],<span class="pl-c1">2</span>,<span class="pl-c1">3</span>))</span></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L997" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="997"></td>
          <td id="LC997" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L998" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="998"></td>
          <td id="LC998" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Our node list now includes $W_1$ as treatments as well! Don&#39;t worry,</td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L999" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="999"></td>

        <tr>
          <td id="L1000" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1000"></td>
          <td id="LC1000" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1001" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1001"></td>
          <td id="LC1001" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-mh"><span class="pl-mh">###</span><span class="pl-mh"> </span>Variable Importance using Targeted Estimation of the value of the ITR</span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1002" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1002"></td>
          <td id="LC1002" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1003" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1003"></td>
          <td id="LC1003" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In the previous sections we have seen how to obtain a contrast between the mean</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1004" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1004"></td>
          <td id="LC1004" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">under the optimal individualized rule and the mean under the observed outcome</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1005" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1005"></td>
          <td id="LC1005" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">for a single covariate --- we are now ready to run the variable importance analysis</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1006" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1006"></td>
          <td id="LC1006" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">for all of our specified covariates. In order to run the variable importance</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1007" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1007"></td>
          <td id="LC1007" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">analysis, we first need to initialize a specification for the TMLE of our</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1008" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1008"></td>
          <td id="LC1008" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">parameter of interest as we have done before. In addition, we need to specify</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1009" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1009"></td>
          <td id="LC1009" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the data and the corresponding list of nodes, as well as the appropriate</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1010" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1010"></td>
          <td id="LC1010" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">learners for the outcome regression, propensity score, and the blip function.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1011" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1011"></td>
          <td id="LC1011" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Finally, we need to specify whether we should adjust for all the other</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1012" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1012"></td>
          <td id="LC1012" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">covariates we are assessing variable importance for. We will adjust for all $W$s</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1013" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1013"></td>
          <td id="LC1013" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in our analysis, and if <span class="pl-c1">`adjust_for_other_A=TRUE`</span>, also for all $A$ covariates</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1014" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1014"></td>
          <td id="LC1014" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">that are not treated as exposure in the variable importance loop.</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1015" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1015"></td>
          <td id="LC1015" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1016" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1016"></td>
          <td id="LC1016" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">To start, we will initialize a specification for the TMLE of our parameter of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1017" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1017"></td>
          <td id="LC1017" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">interest (called a <span class="pl-c1">`tmle3_Spec`</span> in the <span class="pl-c1">`tlverse`</span> nomenclature) simply by calling</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1018" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1018"></td>
          <td id="LC1018" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">`tmle3_mopttx_vim`</span>. First, we indicate the method used for learning the optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1019" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1019"></td>
          <td id="LC1019" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">individualized treatment by specifying the <span class="pl-c1">`method`</span> argument of</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1020" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1020"></td>
          <td id="LC1020" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">`tmle3_mopttx_vim`</span>. If <span class="pl-c1">`method=&quot;Q&quot;`</span>, then we will be using Q-learning for rule</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1021" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1021"></td>
          <td id="LC1021" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">estimation, and we do not need to specify <span class="pl-c1">`V`</span>, <span class="pl-c1">`type`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`learners`</span> arguments</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1022" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1022"></td>
          <td id="LC1022" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the spec, since they are not important for Q-learning. However, if</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1023" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1023"></td>
          <td id="LC1023" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">`method=&quot;SL&quot;`</span>, which corresponds to learning the optimal individualized</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1024" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1024"></td>
          <td id="LC1024" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment using the above outlined methodology, then we need to specify the type</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1025" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1025"></td>
          <td id="LC1025" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of (pseudo) blip we will use in this estimation problem, whether we want to</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1026" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1026"></td>
          <td id="LC1026" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">maximize or minimize the outcome, complex and realistic rules, resource constraint. </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1027" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1027"></td>
          <td id="LC1027" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Finally, for <span class="pl-c1">`method=&quot;SL&quot;`</span> we also need to communicate that we&#39;re interested in learning a</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1028" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1028"></td>
          <td id="LC1028" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rule dependent on <span class="pl-c1">`V`</span> covariates by specifying the <span class="pl-c1">`V`</span> argument. For both</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1029" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1029"></td>
          <td id="LC1029" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">`method=&quot;Q&quot;`</span> and <span class="pl-c1">`method=&quot;SL&quot;`</span>, we need to indicate whether we want to maximize</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1030" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1030"></td>
          <td id="LC1030" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">or minimize the mean under the optimal individualized rule. Finally, we also</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1031" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1031"></td>
          <td id="LC1031" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">need to specify whether the final comparison of the mean under the optimal</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1032" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1032"></td>
          <td id="LC1032" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">individualized rule and the mean under the observed outcome should be on the</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1033" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1033"></td>
          <td id="LC1033" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">multiplicative scale (risk ratio) or linear (similar to average treatment</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1034" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1034"></td>
          <td id="LC1034" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">effect).</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1035" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1035"></td>
          <td id="LC1035" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">
</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1036" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1036"></td>
          <td id="LC1036" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-c1">```{r mopttx_spec_init_vim}</span><span class="pl-s1"></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1037" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1037"></td>
          <td id="LC1037" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">#</span> initialize a tmle specification</span></span></td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
          <td id="L1038" class="blob-num js-line-number js-code-nav-line-number" data-line-number="1038"></td>
          <td id="LC1038" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"><span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-smi">tmle_spec_vim</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> tmle3_mopttx_vim(</span></td>
        </tr>
